external.description:
Alt: Not endorsing Agent Smith's view on humanity.

Just saying that frameworks are often over engineered and built atop each other like Matryoshka dolls.

Frameworks feel like a path to greatness, but they really lead to strong coupling and harder to refactor code.

Making frameworks has been the way up for many people.  Maintaining them is almost always a way to trap yourself into a cycle of technical debt and pain.

I know this much better than most.  I am not immune.

I have made many frameworks.

A few light ones have proved very useful.

Most of them have not proved their utility with time.

The best framework is no framework 

The second best framework is a light framework.

The third best framework is a well-tested stable framework that has barely changed in years.

Keep stuff as close to the language / metal as you can, and live a happier developer life.

Trust me.

I know this lesson painfully well.
external.title: a man in a suit and tie wearing sunglasses is standing in front of a window .

record.text:
Thing of it is, that reduces framework dependency.

Technique is almost always better than tooling.

Took me a long time to learn this, and knowing it helps me make better tools.

There are too many frameworks

Doing too few things

It's a disease of the industry.

( More in alt )
